The staff is warm and welcoming and my daughters are learning and thriving in this environment. The campus has a nice set up with a great outdoor space that feels so comfortable and safe."},{"author":"Momo B.","datePublished":"2021-06-05","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":4},"description":"I am not a member but a neighbor, and this church has been amazing to work with as a member of our community. They are responsive to any issue immediately (broken sprinklers, trees, lights broken) and so happy to communicate and reach out"},{"author":"Taryn B.","datePublished":"2022-02-25","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":1},"description":"Buyer beware! We learned the hard lesson of paying the non refundable deposit at this school. We were under the assumption that covid guidelines would be enforced from county regulations. After our son attended a couple days of school, we realized what they presented was very different than what they practiced. After discussing with the director we decided that their enforcement was not what we originally signed up for. We lost our deposit when we withdrew our son because we believed the director lied to us and defended her employees about a simple issue. 

We thought it was a good school, in a great area and very moderately priced, but were sadly disappointed. Redeemer is very good at sales and getting your deposit. The business model at this school is: great sales, secure deposits, and accept waitlisting lists- but when you find out what you are getting at this school it's very different than what they sell. Covid has made this a difficult time, but there are certain rules that businesses need to follow. Redeemer does not follow these guidelines and they say they do. 

Looking at the other reviews it seems like I'm not the only one who has lost deposits here, that is sad this is what their business is about. We are happy now at a different preschool that does not require 1 month tuition up front- also our new preschool keeps doors and windows open for ventilation which Redeemer does not."},{"author":"Kathleen C.","datePublished":"2021-07-22","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":1},"description":"I had high hopes for this school, as I had heard our new neighbors say what a wonderful experience they had at this school over the years (later I learned it was because of a different Director) Unfortunately, what transpired over the course of 4 1/2 months was highly unacceptable in how this preschool treated my sweet 5 year old son.
We moved during Covid and had picked this school out of many in our new area. My son was eager to begin school after having his last school cut short, due to the pandemic. The director was seemingly pleasant when we met her & the school had reasonable rates for what it was. My son was in the "TK" class.
We realized soon after starting that a couple of moms in the class had it out for our son. He was a little too rambunctious for these kid's mom's and we realized later, that he was being bullied. Always labeled "bad" or "naughty" by the kids in his class & he was always getting tattled on for anything he did. Naturally, my son began to act out; there were a couple of incidents that were normal playground type behavior, but we felt there was something more going on. We asked his teacher almost daily how he was doing, was anything going on, etc. and she would always say, "i'll let you know if anything happens, he is totally fine. There is NOTHING to worry about. He's just being a normal 5 year old boy." Her words. Also, she let us know in a meeting we had with her later that she never uses the words "bad" or "naughty" in her classroom & that those names must be coming from somewhere else (ahem, other kid's parents). Judging by my son's behavior at home, at how he used to cry at night before school, we knew there was something going on. I mean how, in a classroom of 10 kids with 2 teachers can you not realize what is happening??
About to get to the worst part about this school- THEY HAVE A 3 STRIKES POLICY FOR PRESCHOOLERS.
We didn't realize this so called policy even existed until later- when we wanted to pull him out of this terrible place. There is nothing in the parent handbook, school policies, etc. It sounds like it was almost made up, so that they could push us out. We even had a sit down meeting with his teacher face to face, where she told us he was a perfectly normal 5 year old kid & he's just learning- like the rest of the class. She wanted to make us feel like he wasn't a bad kid & that she had his back.  She made zero mention about him having had 2 strikes at this point.
Also during these incidents, my son was sent to the Director's office without notifying us first. Can the teacher's not handle the incident themselves?? That should have been a red flag.
It seems that Redeemer is more worried about the opinions of overbearing & non empathetic parents rather than trying to help & improve the child.  There should have been some type of plan for my son, but I guess they lack the resources & education on this front.
Had they wanted him to stay, they would have created a plan or let us in our their secret 'policy' that he was almost at 3 strikes and that maybe we should consider looking at different schools/options we may have.
I only hope I can warn other parents in the area that if they have a typical 5 year old boy who is a bit active, they should probably steer clear of Redeemer.  As a Christian school, I would have thought they would have more empathy.
I was hopeful this school would provide the nurturing care that my son needed to grow academically, socially and emotionally. In taking the actions they have, they have failed him.
Partnerships between parents and teachers are imperative to a child's total growth. The communication skills to parents at Redeemer are severely lacking.
We hope that maybe they will change their policy so another family doesn't have to go through what our son did & crush our child's confidence & well being.
*** As a follow up several months after pulling him from Redeemer, he is noticeably more happy, confident & is now enjoying another school. His new teacher has even said this about him recently "He is friends with everyone in class and has been such a great addition to our class. He is an absolute JOY to have in our class."
It was clearly the wrong school for my son. It's unfortunate how they treated us, my son & just having a significant lack of empathy of being a nice human. Do better, Redeemer!!!"},{"author":"M M.","datePublished":"2021-03-18","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":2},"description":"I have been sending my children here since 2015. The teachers are wonderful (hence the 2 and not 1 star). They really are the stars of the show. My kids were very ready for kindergarten and I attribute that to the teachers!

My problem is with the administration. Since coming to this school, I have been through two previous directors before the current director. The previous directors were great, always available, and open to suggestions and ideas. I do recognize the uphill battle this director has had to endure with COVID and all of the precautions they are required to take.

BUT......They didn't require masks. They followed OSHA, etc and their recommendations. These websites did recommend that they "try" to enforce mask-wearing, which was not done at all. It seems they took what they wanted from these sites and claimed that three year olds would not be able to wear masks.

When I pressed for an answer as to why they couldn't just mandate masks on their own, I was either ignored or sent a copy and pasted answer that didn't answer my concerns. They could not answer why they just simply couldn't mandate masks. It is not that hard to make that decision for your own school when it is proven to help prevent the spread. Why would you not do all you can to protect these kids?

I unfortunately had to pull my two kids because I felt like they were not doing everything in their power to keep them safe. On top of this, I was being ignored and dismissed with all of my concerns. I would have been happy to open a discussion, but this was never offered. Something the administration should always be available to do.

Again, I do love the teachers and curriculum, and after all of this, they eventually enforced mask-wearing (yay!). Unfortunately, we had already unenrolled and were never invited back."},{"author":"Cheryl C.","datePublished":"2021-09-28","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":1},"description":"I'll preface this review by noting that our experience was a few years ago, with a previous director. Two months after our 3 year old daughter started at Redeemer, she was diagnosed with cancer, and had to stay home for treatment the rest of the school year. By that point, she was already attached to her teachers and classmates, several of whom she knew even before starting there. Seven days after her diagnosis, I specifically emailed the director asking that her spot be saved for her, as we were going to fight as hard as we could for her to get better, and return to her class. By the spring, I realized I hadn't heard from the school about fall enrollment, and when I emailed the director, she said our daughter's spot was taken and she could be put on a waitlist. Our then- four year old daughter had fought hard and bravely to be able to return to normal life and her class- she would have been devastated to not return to her teachers and friends- and after a lengthy email and offer to go to the local news with our story, her spot fortuitously opened up. After her treatment was done, we also heard from several parents in the school that they had tried to plan fundraisers and other events for our daughter, but all of those ideas were shot down by the director. All of her teachers there were good teachers, in fairness, but hopefully your child won't get a life-threatening illness while at Redeemer, because our experience with a supposed Christian school is that you will get no support at all."},{"author":"Christine S.","datePublished":"2016-11-23","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":4},"description":"Well balanced preschool program that focuses on the whole child.
I've visited a number of preschools in the area, including one down the street which we loved, so I can say that this is a really great place for kids.

It is more structured than other preschools in some regards, and has a stronger academic focus. My 4 yr old goes in and she is immediately tasked with practicing tracing and writing letters with her peers at the table. She is also exposed to phonics as they focus on a new letter each week and practice the sounds in a song.  She usually does a craft each week that involves coloring with crayons and gluing pieces together in a collage type format. Not much painting (I'm guessing that some parents object to paint on clothes)

There are also additional classes offered: Spanish, Art, and Science. These are hr long classes offered in the afternoon. After just one class in Spanish, my daughter came home singing songs in Spanish!

The teachers and admin team are super organized and very friendly. They have very strict policies in place, including no nuts of any kind on campus. I got a note when I sent a granola bar in my daughter's lunch and the label read "May contain a trace amount of peanuts..."

It is very much like an elementary school in some regards- complete with room moms and field trips.

In any case, a great choice for preschool education!"},{"author":"Frustrated Parent P.","datePublished":"2018-06-01","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":1},"description":"We had a pretty awful experience with Redeemer through the sign up process. We signed up our daughter after being on the waitlist, and paid a non-refundable deposit for tuition, supplies and registration fee. You have no choice but to sign this as you sign up. A couple months later, we got a diagnosis our daughter had a special need and needed therapy, but the only time to do that was during the time we had class at Redeemer. The other option Redeemer gave us was in the afternoon sessions which didn't work for us, since we work. We withdrew 2+ months before school began and they replaced her spot but refused to give us back our deposit, even after we laid out the circumstance to them. 

We had to take them to court to try to recover it. The judge ruled that even though it's bad business for them to do this and a bad way to treat families of those you're supposed to be helping, they could keep the nearly $500 because they offered us an option B (an option which didn't work for us).  This, also despite the fact that the CA Supreme Court has ruled non-refundable deposits ARE refundable if a replacement "buyer" (student) is found. They can't legally enrich themselves over our unfortunate circumstance, but they--a church preschool--opted to do that. 

We are very frustrated, and not the first family to deal with this. Be wary of what you sign, and the fact that Redeemer's people don't necessarily have your best interests in mind, even when it comes to an unforeseen circumstance surrounding a 3-year-old."},{"author":"Cara M.","datePublished":"2019-09-30","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"Love this school. The teachers are amazing, my child is learning tons and I love all the bonus program options."},{"author":"Karie T.","datePublished":"2017-04-19","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":1},"description":"Warning: This is going to be long

I enrolled my 3 year old in the afternoon class twice a week. I chose afternoon because of the smaller class size since this was his first time in a school environment. In August when he started, the class had 8 children. After fall break, we came back to a full class of 15. This really had an effect on my son in a negative way. He no longer wanted to go to school. I think a big part of this was the noise. the class became VERY Noisy and he just didn't seem to like it.  it got to the point where it was a constant battle trying to get him in the car. He would scream and cry and kick etc. I contacted the school several times regarding this asking for advice. I spoke to his teacher a few times and the director a few times. In late February I spoke to the director again, at which point we both agreed to pull him out for the remainder of the year and try again the next fall. This was at the same time that the fall registration was due. We didn't want to lose his spot for next year but we were also struggling with what to do. We ended up submitted the $625 fee and registration a day late, which they were not pleased about.

 During his "break" I contacted my older sons former Preschool teacher to see if we could go and "visit" her school.( I would have chosen her school to begin with but we moved and she was much farther away. ) She has a very quiet preschool of 6 kids. he loved it from the minute we went to visit. She happened to have an open spot during the afternoons for the rest of the school year so we decided to enroll him through June.

Seeing how much he enjoyed going to the new school, we decided to keep him there for next year and let Reedemer know that he would not be attending the next school year (which starts in August 2017) I then asked for our deposit back. ( $175 was the supply and registration fee and $450 was the cost of tuition for the month of June 2018. June 2018 is a full 15 months away! 

They replied that I would not be getting any of my $625.00 back.

 I understand keeping the deposit and supply fee of $175 since we were "holding his spot" BUT I do not understand nor agree with them keeping the $450 tuition fee for a tuition that will occur 15 months from now.  When I brought this to their attention, they ignored my email for several weeks.

Yes, I signed a contract and i understand that. However, They made ZERO effort to work with us. Especially knowing we were having problems prior.

It gets better! 

Today i finally received a response. They had the nerve to state that I actually owed them March tuition of $280 AND a late fee of $25.00!. When I spoke to The director in February and she agreed that I should pull my son out, there was NO mention of owing  March tuition.  On March 7th, i was asked to send an email back stating my intentions to pull my son out for the remainder of the year for their records, with again, no mention of March tuition. I sent my intentions email on March 8th. 

Here was part of their response that I received today:

"Based on this information, the required 30 days written notice per your signed agreement ended on March 24th, therefore, the March tuition in the amount of $280 was due by March 5th.  It was not received by that date and a late fee of $25 was added for a total of $305 and as of this date, remains unpaid." 

I signed that agreement 10 months ago. it's amazing I didn't remember the part about the written notice! 

Please note, my son did not attend a single day in March, which they were aware of in February.  

One more thing I wanted to add:

In our conversations, they thought a part of the reason for this behavior was because I was giving in to his tantrums of not wanting to go to school.  Honestly, a few times, yes. I felt bad that he screamed and cried about going. I wanted him to want to go to school. I didn't want this to be a punishment or a negative experience. They made me feel like I was not being a good mom and that he was throwing the tantrums because he knew he would get to stay home.  One day I dropped him off and he was crying and clinging to me asking to go home. The teacher just told me to walk away as she picked him up and carried him away. he was reaching for me and screaming and crying.  I felt awful about it but I walked away. 

Fast forward a month of him being in the new school. ( he had about a week or two break between schools) Not ONCE has he thrown a tantrum about going to school. Not once has he kicked and screamed and begged to stay home.  This speaks volumes.  

Their mission appears to be aimed at making money. They are all about the fine print with no regard to our personal situation and how it may be affecting us.  I have three small children, one with medical issues,  to take care of and the last thing our family can afford is to pay money for something like this.   

So much for christian values and caring about families. I will NEVER recommend this school to anyone!"},{"author":"Nikki M.","datePublished":"2016-12-15","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":4},"description":"We are in our second year here and my daughter loves it! The teachers are all very friendly and warm. The playground is super cute with lots of areas for the kids to play. The classrooms are big, clean, and everything is made from wood! They have locked gates and a teacher at each one for pick up and drop off. My only complaint is I wish we had opportunities to meet with the teachers to discuss progress of child. They don't offer that until they are 4, and only once half way through the year. In addition, I feel like they could do better at communicating some things, but overall we are pleased to be sending our daughter here."},{"author":"J M.","datePublished":"2017-03-06","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":1},"description":"Poor service and lack of empathy from front office.  Lack of educational structure and teachers and staff are indifferent.  Would not recommend."},{"author":"Ursula M.","datePublished":"2016-12-15","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":1},"description":"We had been a family with 3 children at this school for the past 5 years. There have been recent changes that include a new school director. I have been compelled to withdraw my 2 girls who were in the Kindergarten program and in the 3's program. This new director is so rude and dismissive of parental concerns. It is obvious to me that she does not care much for the families at the school. This used to be a sweet, family orientated, nurturing school environment - not anymore. So sad. Miss Dee seems more like a stone faced, cold hearted prison warden than a nurturing preschool director. If you want your children to feel safe, secure and loved look elsewhere. I would imagine most of the teachers who have been there for years will soon be leaving working under this new director. They have already lost a kindergarten teacher and quite a few families have withdrawn from the school with similar complaints like ours. I honestly don't know how this woman is working in a preschool."},{"author":"Jennifer R.","datePublished":"2017-11-08","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"As a mother, we all want to find the best, the most caring and trusted preschool for our little ones. And I found that in Redeemer By The Sea Preschool. Like many of you,  I toured quite a few preschools before we landed on Redeemer By The Sea Preschool. When my family needed the care, Ms. Dee the director and Ms. Rhonda were there to advise and provide what my family needed. Before enrolling, I toured the school twice. Every time I was there early, I observed that other kids seemed to enjoy being there.  My son James has been super-well-taken care of and taught by Ms. Bonnie and Ms. Nina. I just enrolled him in the Enrichment program ago since September, but so far it's been great and he learns to love art. I even sat and observe in both Enrichment classes (Art and Spanish) unexpectedly since I forgot I enrolled him in Enrichment program and I came to pick him up early. A few points I want to make. (1) For the lady who complained about the noise of the 15 children class. My son is extremely sensitive to noise. But so far he has no problem and he can't wait to go to school. Mind you, my son is in the AM class. My only guess is your son (who might have been 3 or 4 at the time) might need his nap/rest instead of going to the PM class. When kids that age get tired, they'd cry and act out since they did not know how to express what they needed. (2)This school is very well-organized and the parents need to read the documents and the contracts of what we are signing. I knew I didn't and I missed out on important details. Fortunately, my overlook in the details did not cause me any monetary setback.  And I learnt from this mistake to always read carefully what paper/documents that come to my hands.  (3) Every preschool will always function as a business, regardless of if it is church affiliated since it will serve a variety of different parents and different personalities. Without written documents and rules, then chaos will definitely follow.  (4) I toured enough preschools around Carlsbad to attest that Redeemer By the Sea preschool is the best choice in this area."}],"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingValue":2.5,"reviewCount":14}}

{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Artisan Knitworks","image":"https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/yqvGBLLpXkp429pjj5BL2g/l.jpg","priceRange":"Moderate","telephone":"(734) 562-2682","address":{"streetAddress":"105 N Main St","addressLocality":"Chelsea","addressCountry":"US","addressRegion":"MI","postalCode":"48118"},"review":[{"author":"MaryLou D.","datePublished":"2016-10-27","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"This is a very small store, comparatively, although there is more yarn in the downstairs which I almost missed seeing. Because I knit mostly for charity I am always looking for lower priced yarn and mostly acrylics because that is what the hospital's request. If I was needing something good quality for myself or for a gift this would be the place for me. 

The owner informed me they are open everyday except Mondays. I mentioned the other Yelp review which chided them for being closed on a Sunday and he told me they had closed on Sundays during the summer only, being a slower season. He invited me to stop by anytime to just sit on one of their comfortable couches or chairs and knit or crochet for the pure enjoyment of it, which I thought was a very nice invitation. I had occasion to use the restroom and it was nice and clean. 

I found some Christmasy looking yarn that I think will make adorable baby hats, a mixture of green and red. I bought it and left happy. It was worth the stop. Susan"},{"author":"Loreen K.","datePublished":"2016-12-12","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":4},"description":"Nice people, wonderful fiber, decent needle selection.  They have good sales and if in need, good classes."},{"author":"Melissa C.","datePublished":"2012-12-01","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"I've visited 5 yarn shops this month in search of a particular shade of red in chunky yarn. I noted that instead of the traditional table & chair workspace they had couches & stuffed chairs. Very inviting! Who wants to sit in a hard chair at a table to knit? Even though there are other great stores, this was the first one that felt homelike. I could cozy down for hours."},{"author":"Brik I.","datePublished":"2017-08-19","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"Come for the yarn, stay for the conversation, in the comfy 'living room' at the front of the store. The owners are an adorable pair, friendly and helpful.  Shops like these are like little gems, Farmington Hills is lucky to have Artisan Knitworks!"}],"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingValue":4.5,"reviewCount":5}}

{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Robin Hills Farm","image":"https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Avv046OqRfZaaYZth7jEPQ/l.jpg","telephone":"(734) 536-6576","address":{"streetAddress":"20390 N M-52","addressLocality":"Chelsea","addressCountry":"US","addressRegion":"MI","postalCode":"48118"},"review":[{"author":"Derek J.","datePublished":"2020-05-22","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"This place is amazing. Picture a bar that is 100
acres of just nature. (~2.5 miles of trails) with some scattered benches. This place is perfect for distancing and you are welcome to bring the party with you with exception of drinks. Games, food, etc..  Open 9-4 Thursday, Friday, and Saturday 12-9. True local gem!"},{"author":"Bailey D.","datePublished":"2022-04-10","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"The perfect spot for live music and drinks! Best outdoor seating option in the area. Also so beautiful for private events such as weddings."},{"author":"Maeve D.","datePublished":"2021-05-03","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":4},"description":"This is a fantastic, family-friendly nature venue with a full bar. They have 140 acres with 3 miles of walking trails. They also are a possible wedding venue! Located just down the street from downtown Chelsea, it's a nice place to enjoy the views, quiet or music (live bands in the evenings), and a beverage. While the drink selection is smaller, the staff is super friendly and welcoming. They have had food trucks on Friday and Saturday evenings as well, otherwise they have some snacks available for purchase. Highly recommend checking this place out!"},{"author":"Martha R.","datePublished":"2017-10-17","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":4},"description":"Went on a tour with the Yelpers and had a lovely time. The person giving the tour did a nice job, but it might have been nice to keep the time a little shorter as it was right at dinner time and we were surrounded by food that we basically couldn't eat. ;) Ha.

I did end up buying some food stuffs at the end of the tour: arugula (very delicious, though not as good as what I grew at home), cucumber, peppers, and eggs. The eggs were the star of the food for SURE. If it weren't so far away, I'd be heading over there right now to get some more! So so good.

The facility was not quite completely up and running during our tour, but the vision of what it's going to be looks just amazing. I highly suggest stopping in and checking it out. Very excited to have a place like this around."},{"author":"Andrea R.","datePublished":"2020-09-18","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"This place is a hidden treasure.it has a super cool vibe, like a mix between a cool Malibu restaurant and an aspen ski lodge. They look like they serve food at times but mostly at this point it is bring your own food and they have a really nice bar.  You can sit outside anywhere on the property with tons of nice tables with beautiful overlooks.   We also loved the greenhouse which is Pinterest perfect for a wedding or event.  We will absolutely be going back."},{"author":"Annette J.","datePublished":"2017-07-10","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"I had the pleasure of encountering the Robin Hills Farm at the Ann Arbor Westside Farmer's Market a few weeks ago. I got a dozen eggs and, let me tell you, they were maybe the best eggs I've ever had. Bright orange yolks, rich and flavorful. I have been dreaming about these eggs ever since! I just haven't had a chance to go back and get more! 

The staff running their booth was SO nice. Super chatty and really lovely. With my egg purchase, they generously gave me a lovely tote bag (which I've been using regularly toting around my laptop!) and some literature on the farm itself. I learned so much! I discovered that they have a huge space in Chelsea right off M-52 (129 acres!) that you can tour, a garden you can volunteer in, they also offer classes, etc. They even have an amphitheater where they host events. Next week they're hosting a local theatre company's performance of A Midsummer Night's Dream. They also have a summer day camp for kids to learn about ecology, art, and science. 

Their website explains that they,"have an organic garden, a mushroom forest, a commercial aquaponics system located in our fully-automated greenhouse, 10 acres of pasture for raising happy and healthy livestock, and spring-fed ponds stocked with rainbow trout." But as far as I know you have to contact them ahead of time to take advantage of that, you can't just stop in. 

Can't wait to try more items from them and take a tour of the farm sometime very soon!"},{"author":"Alyssa P.","datePublished":"2020-09-09","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"We were so excited that Robin Hills Farm opened up at the time that it did! This place is beautiful and was everything we wanted in a wedding venue. The barn is beautiful and well kept! It truly does look like it is brand new. There is an upstairs floor level that is perfect for getting ready. I would highly recommend that your Bride stays there to get ready! There are big mirrors, couches, tables, and plenty of outlets to use if necessary. It also has a nice overhang of the reception downstairs. This property is gorgeous and it feels completely secluded from the other areas surrounding it. We had the entire place to ourselves and it made for great memories and beautiful pictures. Adam is wonderful to work with and all of the event staff was extremely sweet and accommodating in every aspect! We couldn't have chosen a better place with better people!"},{"author":"Emily S.","datePublished":"2021-10-07","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"Exceptional customer service, great music, patio, and drinks. Check out online the music and food trucks that change weekly to go along with the experience. As a whole with all these experiences it helps the community come together and have a place to meet up for a great meaningful time."},{"author":"Alfred B.","datePublished":"2018-02-03","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"Visiting the Robin Hills Farm is an adventure.  Located just a short distance outside of beautiful, downtown Chelsea Michigan the farm has plenty of parking.  They were, last time I was there, working on smoothing the entrance area for handicapped patrons but will assist in every way to get everyone up to the restaurant/lodge/headquarters.

The grounds are beautiful.  They have been recently carved out of an old farmstead that had been worked by a family of Michiganders for generations.  They now display various types of farmland landscapes that are common across Michigan.  They are sensitive to the environment and work to support and increase the wildlife in the area.  The work they do also involves ensuring that the plants and other creatures that inhabit the area are kept in stable and then growing populations.

In Spring you may be able to see the elusive Blue Bird nesting and flying about.  There are turtles, frogs and the deer sure like the grazing. 
There are beautiful locations for outdoor parties and weddings.  Plenty of space for other activities too.  

Robin Hills Farm is not short on science either.  Their organic vegetable fields and their greenhouse which features cutting edge aquaculture as well as cold weather growing facilities is a wonderful sight to behold and learn from.  They were very kind to us when we were there.  My favorite part about the place is that everyone who goes there seems to belong.  Have fun!"},{"author":"Jon F.","datePublished":"2017-09-25","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":4},"description":"I'm going to rate this review as 'under construction', because the same can be said for Robin Hills Farm.  We attended a Yelp event over the weekend, so I learned a lot about the farm and you should know this place is a work in progress.  They've been around for 3 years and claim to be an Eco-friendly farm.  The place isn't officially open to the public, though they are hoping to be so as early as November.  It also isn't a full production farm, as it's geared as much to education and learning as it is to farming.  For example, they have a pretty cool vegetable garden which includes two full size green houses, but they aren't supplying the country side with produce.  You will be able to find their produce at local farmer's markets.

I loved the place.  It's big and has several areas to visit (garden, animal pastures, an aquaponics building, ponds) but isn't like going to a working farm, so you weren't overwhelmed with anything.  The pigs and other animals were friendly (pigs were a blast) and the employees did a good job educating us.

I had a geat vibe from the place, and I think as it opens up, it will be a great place to visit.  They are currently mostly about classes and field trip events, but check back in 2018!"},{"author":"Caroline D.","datePublished":"2018-02-03","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":3},"description":"Beautiful facility. Menu appeared better than it actually was. Some fine tuning and attention to detail would be good; maybe we hit them on an off day."},{"author":"Todd A.","datePublished":"2017-07-21","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":2},"description":"I was recently at Robin Hills Farm for a theatrical performance at their outdoor venue. This is a review of that space.

The location is quite pretty, but be forewarned that it is, in significant ways, still a construction zone. The parking area is unfinished, as is the driveway that leads in to the complex. Ticket sales and vending (high-priced snacks, farm goods, and chachki with their logo) are done on the edge of the parking area under a temporary tent structure. The restrooms are also located here in a completed structure.

The performance venue itself is down a steep, grassy, uneven hillside from the parking area. I nearly tripped in a couple of significant holes. It had been some time since the venue was last mowed, as well. Clearly, this is not ADA-compliant in any sense, and was rather shocking that they thought this arrangement was OK, especially considering that the audience had a significant number of older members.

The stage is defined at its back edge by a parabolic concrete wall, meant clearly to reflect sound back toward the audience. The seating area consists of several tiers of grass with concrete walls at the back edge of each. The concrete wall behind the actors did reflect sound toward the audience, which was good, else it would have bene very hard to hear them. However, much of the performance took place off the front edge of the stage, meaning that the direct sound from the actors and the reflection off the wall were slightly out of sync with each other - rather distracting and confusing.

The tiered seating worked well enough, except that some people brought chairs and others sat on the grass, so that those sitting on chairs blocked the view of the grass sitters. This was problematical.

For some reason, a microphone on a stand was placed out in front of the stage. It was apparently connected to a single box speaker that was mounted on a tripod and placed to one side of the stage. It was never used, but did interfere with the performance. What they really needed was wireless microphones on each of the performers, with a proper sound system to bring those voices out to the audience. Such a system would likely include speakers to the sides of the stage and behind the audience.

Curiously, staff at the venue seemed to think that what they did in the line of sight of the audience behind the stage was somehow magically invisible. One person stood with a large camera kitted out with a telephoto lens photographing the audience. (Did you ask our permission to be photographed? hmmm...) Other staff casually walked past behind the stage or, in one instance, drove a noisy vehicle past, all of which was quite distracting. What were they thinking?

In sum, this venue has potential, but it needs a considerable amount of work and investment in additional equipment. The staff also need to learn what it means to respect the performers whom they invite in and the audience that pays to be there."},{"author":"Sheila Q.","datePublished":"2018-01-18","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"The restaurant at Robin Hills Farm is finally open! I had brunch last Saturday with my daughter and friends. The food and service was amazing. My favorite dish was the rainbow trout. The meat was really tender with great flavor. This is definitely a very nice place to bring the family and friends for brunch. This was my first farm to table experience, I could tell how fresh and flavorful the food was. Besides, the restaurant is right on the lake with a beautiful view. Afterwards, we shopped around their retail area, they have a great selection of local products. They even carry products from Cherry Republic. We all had a great time. I'll be back :-)"},{"author":"Angie W.","datePublished":"2017-12-22","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"We went to the Christmas extravaganza.   It was simple and fun.   Very good lunch and gift shop as well"}],"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingValue":4.5,"reviewCount":14}}

{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"St Mary of Chelsea","telephone":"(734) 475-3250","address":{"streetAddress":"14200 E Old US Highway 12","addressLocality":"Chelsea","addressCountry":"US","addressRegion":"MI","postalCode":"48118"},"review":[]}

{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Sylvan Crossing Clubhouse","telephone":"(734) 433-1111","address":{"streetAddress":"23351 Redwood Dr","addressLocality":"Chelsea","addressCountry":"US","addressRegion":"MI","postalCode":"48118"},"review":[{"author":"Michael B.","datePublished":"2021-02-22","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":1},"description":"Complaint
We rent here and we love our neighbours and the community but the management sucks. When things break down or need repair, don't expect them to come, because, they will not. Three years we have waited for windows to be replaced; they leak air horribly and every year we get told that it is on the list.  The bathroom water control, to turn the water on and off, or to take a shower broke months ago.  
They insisted on a walkthrough in the midst of Covid putting our family at risk, but when I wanted to go to the office, they said that they would not let me in because of Covid.  Since then (over a month ago) they have not been back to repair a single issue.  We are still taking baths and showers with pliers (anyone that would like photo evidence of this feel free to email us).  Over three years ago when we moved in we asked them to replace the 15 year old carpet that was in disrepair, stained and honestly disgusting.  They have refused and even turned down our request to professionally clean the carpets.  All of this while still charging nearly $1600 per month.  Recently we logged online to our Sylvan Crossing account to pay our bill and saw charges in the amount of $100 for a non lease renewal fee (we have not had a lease in 2.5 years).  We were not given any notice of the increase. Just logged in and there it was. Nice business practices!
 Or how about when our terminally ill son was home on hospice?
 One evening we lost air conditioning in half the house, we called the emergency maintenance number and got a call back from management, where we were informed that they would address it in the morning.
 Our son was sweating and couldn't breathe due to the heat so  I contacted a contractor friend of mine who called an HVAC friend of his and they came over and made the repairs that night.
Management never called us back.
The electrical wiring in the home is so bad that we doubled our renters insurance coverage due to fear of loss of property. 
Would you like to have a very high sewage and water bill?  Then move here - it will be close to $200 per month.  
 The last time we posted a bad review for Sylvan crossing they promptly removed it.
 I guess it's true...
 The truth hurts."}],"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingValue":1,"reviewCount":1}}

Great for date night or with a group."},{"author":"Fox E.","datePublished":"2018-02-01","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":4},"description":"Not to be confused with the other DCH (Dat C*ck Hard) which probably happens to you fairly often if you check out the pix I post.

One of the standouts is this Dallas comedy house where I recently got dragged to a performance and was surprised how much I enjoyed it in particular the excellent intimate and well-designed venue.

It'd be better if Jamie T featured here."},{"author":"Lyn J.","datePublished":"2019-09-11","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"I enjoyed my time here. It is actually the first place I've been to in Downtown Dallas since moving to Texas. The building is spacious inside with many different rooms holding different events. Stand up open mic in one (free admission on Tues when I went), improvisation in another, classes, etc. They have a bar and a nice outdoor patio just off of it. Nice fun photos that adorn the halls as you walk down the aisles, and the staff are uber friendly. I wouldn't hesitate to go here again for an evening out."},{"author":"Frank J.","datePublished":"2019-12-22","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"I attended the date night improv and had my expectations exceeded. The comedians were hilarious and the acting was super smooth. I haven't laughed that hard ever at a local comedy show but I'd for sure recommend this location to anyone looking for a good laugh. The food and drinks are also not super expensive and there was no drink requirement which was very nice and surprising. The jokes were also much more thoughtful and funny rather than simply resorting to racism to get some cheap laughs (I'm looking at you Lol Comedy)"},{"author":"Aaliyah W.","datePublished":"2018-01-24","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":4},"description":"I was able to venture (45 min drive might I add) to the Dallas Comedy House last night to meet up w/a group from MeetUp. The 1st thing that I would suggest people prepare for is parking, if there are other events going on in the area. Although I didn't have an issue finding a spot (I parked a 3 min walk away). Upon entering you walk up to a podium & present your ID & get a stamp on your hand. To the left is the bar area then to the right is a doorway that leads to the bathrooms & the 2 comedy rooms. The 1st room is for stand-up, the 2nd is for Improv. We went into the Improv room, which had a stage & some high & low tables for seating. The setting was quite small & intimate for the most part. Now for the show, it was decent. I have never been to an improv show so I didn't know what to expect. The 1st half, people went up in groups by levels; the 2nd half people were numbered off into 5 groups. I did have quite a few laughs but it was easy to see who has been doing it for a while & who hasn't. 

I did also try some popcorn & a shot of "WOO-IE CK*", whatever the heck thats suppose to be. The shot hit the spot though that's for sure. Furthermore, would I return? Yes, only if it was for a group meet up w/friends. Overall their new location seems really nice with an outdoor patio and everything, and I'd be willing to come back for a show one of these nights."},{"author":"Ellen F.","datePublished":"2019-09-29","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"I couldn't have imagined a better place than DCH to be in my life. {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Dallas International School","image":"https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/fG_xscTpIiWYNa6ji1n13w/l.jpg","telephone":"(469) 250-0001","address":{"streetAddress":"17811 Waterview Pkwy","addressLocality":"Dallas","addressCountry":"US","addressRegion":"TX","postalCode":"75252"},"review":[{"author":"Alexandre M.","datePublished":"2022-06-06","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":1},"description":"Horrible school, i was there from K-8 and I understand that I was a less then ideal student. While the Dallas public schools in our area are good, DIS is an investment where I can see the rewards on a daily basis--new French words, new friends, new memories being made. We love DIS!"},{"author":"Eve B.","datePublished":"2015-04-24","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":4},"description":"Wonderful school . Teaches in the French curriculum. Students and staff are wonderful 
I go in for after school activities and the school campus is wonderful and modern"},{"author":"Tom G.","datePublished":"2017-10-19","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"With extreme nationalism running rampant, Dallas International School is a breath of fresh air. A dedicated and well-trained international staff helps educate and nurture true global citizens. We've been sending our daughter to DIS since Maternelle 1 (pre-school). We lived in California for a few years and found a similar school that she was able to jump right into. We are back in Dallas and at DIS and my 6th grader is fluent in English and French, speaks a little Spanish, and is now learning Mandarin. Not only does the school offer challenging curriculum but it expands minds and helps kids see other viewpoints. The student body is as close knit and supportive as you can get with tweens and teens. My daughter's future is bright and her options are boundless thanks to the Dallas International School."},{"author":"Ilene J.","datePublished":"2015-08-21","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"Wow, what a difference a new administration can make. Yep, I wrote a negative review 4 years ago and we left for the exact reasons that were expressed in that review. 

But now we have decided to return to Dallas International School. 

Why? Because it is the only school in Dallas:Fort Worth that truly offers an exciting learning environment, an international education and the opportunity to meet people from around the world. It also offers the best IB (international baccalaureate programme) in the area. 

These are the reasons why we came to Dallas International School in the first place, and spent 9 years there before leaving disappointed with the previous administration. 

After hearing that things have changed, that there is a terrific headmaster, that the school is organized, that the faculty is highly educated and supportive, we have decided to give it another go. The newer facility is also very nice as well. 

So far, I can say that we are very impressed with all the upgrades. Now I can say: great concept, great implementation."},{"author":"Brent B.","datePublished":"2016-06-28","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":1},"description":"Beware.  As another reviewer aptly points out " All in all, the school is primarily focused on the French students and the French culture, and makes a poor attempt at being an International school."

After relocating to Dallas from Washington State with a freshman high schooler achieving a 4.0 through Junior high, including pre=AP, we had high hopes for college prep that was promised in a private school education experience expanding her multi-lingual capabilities in an IB program.  

I could go on an on about the horrific experience at DIS (high school IB program) , but will sum it up here in bullet points:
- the headmaster considers himself a "CEO" as in 'running a business'.  This mindset is pervasive and reflected in the teachers he hires - few have the child's best interest at heart, they rarely make themselves available for after / during school hours access and all have second jobs or other outside priorities.
- the teacher turnover is virtually 100% in all subjects.  They all have second jobs or other higher priority interests.  A typical example are teachers that are there to get cost offsets for their own children.  Very few (if any) have IB training or experience.  Good luck trying to help your child navigate the syllabus, as often there isn't one because the teachers are winging it.  The headmaster seems to value teacher education levels (e.g. PhD) over and above any high school or educational teaching experience.  Just imagine your child having to deal with turnover in some of the more challenging subjects, such as 3 Economics teachers, 2 Biology teachers and 3 chemistry teachers in a three year time span.  The headmaster is bad enough, but the teachers are totally disengaged and often firing DIS and leaving, even mid year it was so bad.  And new hires (with other jobs, priorities) ended up making the children attend school from 8:30 to 5:00 pm to accommodate a teachers outside activities!
- No AP, SAT, ACT prep - None.  there was some feeble attempt at AP prep, but was made clear by the headmaster that this was not a priority (despite parent demands to incorporate into the curriculum).  
- Outside tutors required.  Because the teaching experience is so bad, you had better budget for outside tutors if you are striving for better than a C average grade for your child.  Same for AP prep, SAT and/or ACT prep.

Unless you are a French Ex-Pat looking for a school to help educate your child for assimilation back into a Euro educational system, you are wasting your time and money and RISKING your child's future by going to this school (at least at the high school level).

If your child plans to attend a US college and you want them to be well prepared for college life and have the best chance of getting into the college of their choice - this is NOT the high school for your family.  If you want a private education, there are FAR better choices.  Public Schools in Plano are head and shoulders above this place.

Bottom Line: Educational Malpractice is how I would sum up DIS High School's IB Program."},{"author":"DD S.","datePublished":"2015-02-19","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":4},"description":"We came from a sister school in Washington (FASPS), and as much as we liked that school, we like DIS better. Much more laid back, and the other parents are nowhere near as snooty as they were in WA."},{"author":"ernie c.","datePublished":"2012-11-19","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"The Dallas Int'l School offers an amazing experience where our children have flourished the last 5 years.  Like many Dallas families, we only speak English our in home.  

We wanted our girls to have a much broader experience - to learn to think with 'all their brain' and receive all the benefits the research has proven that an early, multilingual education brings to a child.  DIS is all that, and more.

Teachers are highly committed, parents involved, small classroom size and very well-behaved kids.  

There are parents that will be unhappy no matter where their kids go (that's just how they are). 

For parents that embrace the merits of a multilingual, multicultural environment - and want their kids to get an OUTSTANDING education in the process - should check out DIS.   

And ask about recent national test scores, the colleges the recent graduating class attended, their scholarship amounts, etc.....  It's a tremendous educational value."},{"author":"Mrs D.","datePublished":"2012-08-24","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"So far there has been only one, very one-sided review from a parent with a child for whom the school was not a good fit.

Not all schools fit all children.

It is true DIS is academically challenging. The French system is much more challenging, in terms of content and in terms of intellectual rigor, than the American system. 

So if you have an academically challenged child,  or a child who really isn't interested much in learning, then this is definitely not the school for you.  

If you have a child who struggled to learn English as a first language, then this school is definitely not for you.  Children take not only French, but Spanish, and at 6th grade can take Mandarin Chinese.  So from age 3, all children are working in 3 languages.

It is not true, as stated another review, that the focus is primarily on French.  In the early grades,the school is 40% English, 40% French and about 20% Spanish.  The ratio slowly switches as children get older, such that there is majority French instruction by Middle School, but there is still a substantial amount of English (it's probably 60 to 65%  instruction in French by the Middle School level).  BUT this just means the content is taught in French; it doesn't mean they are learning French all of that time  (they are already pretty fluent by then).  They are doing math, biology, physics, computer science, history,  geography, etc. and they do many of these subjects in both English and French.

I have two children at the school, one in Middle and one in Elementary school, and both started at age 3.  I have never hired tutors, and there is alot of homework starting in about 3rd grade.  There is homework help at the school for French, for those children who don't have anyone at home who speaks French. 

Most DIS kids are fairly fluent by the 4th grade or so, so they don't necessarily need help with language beyond that point.

There are teachers at the school who tutor if you need it (I think it's sort of reasonable to expect that if a child is learning a language and no one at home speaks it,you might need some outside help now and then).

My experience with the French teachers has also been nothing but positive.  The French teachers are excellent.  They are recruited from among teachers in France, where teaching is a competitive profession, where it's actually rather difficult to become a teacher, and where teacher training is much more extensive than in the US.

I know some people sometimes perceive that the English instruction is sometimes not as strong as the French instruction, but what can I say, the American system academically just isn't as strong, so when you have the two side by side, it shows.

Does that mean the English teachers are not good?  No, it means the French educational system is stronger than the American one, and that, it seems to me, is an argument for putting your child in this school.

My children have excelled at the school. My son scores above the 95th percentile on American standardized tests.

I know other parents of children who started at age 3 and went up through MIddle or High school who have the same experience.  I also know that  one of the DIS graduating Seniors last year got a President's Scholarship at SMU this year, and that is the most prestigious scholarship the school gives.   Given that it was a small graduating class, that is quite impressive.

Other DIS graduates have gone on to other universities and earned the equivalent of a year of credit based on their IB scores; in many cases, they have gone right into upper-level courses, and this is especially true in languages.  Some children have gone to universities in Canada, where tuition is much lower than in the US, and where DIS students are more competitive than most American students.

As I said, this is clearly a school for academically-oriented children and families.  If you want your child to go to college on an athletic scholarship, you probably ought to look elsewhere, but if you want a child who comes out at 12th grade with a better education than most college-educated Americans have, this is probably the place for you."},{"author":"Scott N.","datePublished":"2015-06-12","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"I happened upon the below review by accident and felt compelled to respond.  Let me start by saying that my son has been attending DIS for two years.  He is now in first grade.  The below reviewer neglects to mention whether her review is based on a personal experience with the school or based upon feedback she has heard from others.  My review is based on my first-hand observations..  

At the outset, the assertion that communication is "non-existent" is untrue.  I have a daughter at Parish Episcopal, and I can say without reservation, that DIS does a better job of keeping me informed.  I receive multiple communications DAILY from staff and teachers at DIS.  Teachers will regularly update us on daily classroom activities, which sometimes include pictures of the children performing the activities being described.  Frankly, I love being at my computer at work and receiving a picture of what my child is doing at that very moment.  I've never had a school do that before.  The assertion that communication is "non-existent" is simply false.  

The comment that there is "some anti-American sentiment" is equally untrue.  I am a gun toting, conservative Texan and a staunch supporter of our American military, and I assure you that if I EVER sensed any anti-American sentiment, I would whip my boy out of that school so fast that it would make your head spin.  I love this country, and I would never tolerate anything "anti-American" and surely would never voluntarily expose my boy to it.  

The reviewer further asserts that "there are issues concerning the education of the non-French speakers".  I don't know what she means, but I don't speak French, and my boy didn't speak French before attending.  He is doing great, and his studies are on par with his similarly aged cousins, except that my boy is fluent in French.  And the school does offer a summer introductory course.  

The "social issues" analysis is ridiculous and shameful.  DIS has a zero tolerance rule regarding physical contact.  They are actually very strict.  The fact is that these children are very closely monitored and loved.  Today was my son's last day of school for the year, and the teachers and assistants were very emotional - some were weeping.  My boy actually says that he "loves" his teacher and her assistant.  I cannot recount the number of occasions that my boy was ill or was struggling with something, only to be comforted by a school staff member or teacher.  My wife and I regularly express to each other how fortunate we were to have him surrounded by people that love him.  The assertion that the teachers don't "nurture" is categorically, unequivocally false, and it saddens me that someone would characterize them in that manner.  These are simply wonderful people that love what they do.

As for the school's responsiveness, once again, I cannot give them higher praise.  The school and staff are extremely responsive. 

As for the curriculum, my boy is only in first grade, so I don't have first-hand experience, but I do know that SMU awarded the President's Scholarship to a recent graduate of DIS.  Here is how SMU describes the recipient of this award:

"The President's Scholars Program is awarded to students who have shown exemplary academic and leadership skills. The award provides full tuition and fees as well as study abroad. Students who live on campus also receive a scholarship for room and board. For consideration for the President's Scholarships, the highest academic awards given by the University, students must have exceptional achievement on the SAT or ACT and in their high school curriculum."

The President's Scholarship is awarded to only 20-25 freshmen.  So, not only did this DIS graduate gain admission to SMU, but he also had what it took to procure a scholarship that was awarded to only 22 of its entering freshmen.  

Suffice to say, I am 100% satisfied with from I have experienced with this school so far.  The high school students I have met seem incredibly well adjusted and talented.  It is simply a wonderful academic institution."},{"author":"A. M.","datePublished":"2011-07-05","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":1},"description":"I went to this school for years before I finally ended leaving. Though the lower school was okay, the upper level teachers are abusive and have no compassion for their students or the subjects they teach. The school does have issues with physical abuse. Slapping, kicking, and punching are regular on the playground. Most of the teachers are washed up french teachers who could not get better jobs with their foreign degrees. Therefore, they seem to harbor ill feelings toward the school and with it, the students. The administration turns a blind eye to abuse from the teachers. A teacher who continuously verbally and physically abused enjoyed employment at D.I.S for over ten years despite parental complaints. Instead of firing the teacher, parents were pressured to move their students elsewhere ( Three during my time at the school).   

As for the psychological effects on the students, most of my peers who stayed ended up socially awkward. I currently work with some current students from D.I.S. At even their young ages, I can see the crippling effects of the school. 

Academically,The French-centric nature of the school can cause problems in later years. Students leave D.I.S with limited, if any, knowledge of American History or tradition. I strongly suggest a traditional private or public school. If the bi-lingual track is a must for your child, consider sending them for their formative language years. No child should stay at the school past 3rd grade. Consider talking to students who have experienced both D.I.S and another school."},{"author":"Tish T.","datePublished":"2015-04-16","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"DIS is an international school that gives children and parents seeking a worldly point of view.  Our kids have been there since 3 years old and have had a great experience.  So much so that they will not even consider going to another school.  There are many teachers who tutor privately."},{"author":"Rhea S.","datePublished":"2011-12-20","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"I think it's important to provide some balance to the only review on Yelp about DIS, as it appears to have been written by someone with an axe to grind and in no way represents our experience nor the experience of the many friends we've made there. It also cites an incorrect address for the primary school--it's actually 6039 Churchill Way.

My wife and I weren't entirely comfortable with the idea of sending our kids to a private school, but we loved our neighborhood and the public school options were unfortunately seriously deficient. We didn't want to move to the burbs, so we went looking for a private school in Dallas that would teach our children (as we do) that there are more important things in the world than amassing and displaying wealth, which turned out to be a really difficult proposition. However, we found exactly what we were looking for at DIS. We have two sons, 6 and 3 years old--our older son is in his 3rd year at DIS and our 3 year old just started this year. We've been overjoyed with the education they're receiving and with the friends from all over the world that all of us have made through the school. It's amazing to hear our older son helping his little brother with French pronunciation and teaching him how to count in French. We've actually been inspired to get Rosetta Stone for French as a Christmas gift for each other so we can keep up with them as they start to speak (and perhaps conspire) with each other more and more in a foreign language. Everyone at the school has taken a genuine personal interest in our children's development. Amazingly, one of the teaching assistants who moved to California when her husband transferred jobs still emails us regularly to check on our younger son's progress since he had a bit of a challenge starting school so young (at 3 years and 2 months). Thanks to her help and the attention of his teachers and other teaching assistants, not to mention all the friends he's made, he now looks forward to school and it's sometimes difficult to extract him at the end of the day.

Since my wife and I both work full-time, we were especially gratified that DIS offers excellent after school care until 6 pm, with great activities for the kids. Our boys have been exposed to karate, yoga, circus (taught by ex-Cirque de Soleil performers!), gymnastics, soccer, and drama, with the opportunities only continuing to expand as they get older. And, for what we would argue is a much more interesting education, the price at DIS is still significantly less than most other Dallas private schools. If you're looking for a school with a great football team and lots of Bentleys in carpool line, this is not the place for you. If you want your children to be in a challenging yet nurturing environment that prepares them to value and understand the world outside of the provincial Dallas establishment, DIS is a great choice."}],"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingValue":4,"reviewCount":13}}

{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"The Clifton School at Clifton","telephone":"(404) 636-4073","address":{"streetAddress":"1700 Clifton Rd NE","addressLocality":"Atlanta","addressCountry":"US","addressRegion":"GA","postalCode":"30329"},"review":[{"author":"Gi G.","datePublished":"2014-07-29","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"As of the writing of this review, there is no listing for The Clifton School at Clairmont.  I didn't realize how good Clifton School was for my son until I moved to another state.  Clifton School is truly a one-of-a-kind experience.
Things I loved:
1)Smaller class sizes- My son was first in one of the infant classrooms and then transitioned to a toddler classroom.  There were about 8 kids per one AM or PM teacher and an additional assistant.
2)Reggio Emilia approach to teaching- You can check out a better definition on Wikipedia.  
-Basically, the approach believes in discovery learning through exploration and creativity.  Each child is allowed his or her own learning style.  Group learning is important too (my son at 20 months could say the names of his classmates).  There is a curriculum coordinator who goes classroom to classroom to see how the kids are learning.  At a point in the year, the coordinator/team calls you to let you know how your child is doing.  Also, there are sit down meetings with teachers.
-It's actually much bigger than just a way of learning.  The approach also believes in an open curriculum so that teachers can change plans based on children learning.  
-The physical environment is important too.  Reggio schools have open areas with piazzas.  Kids aren't just shuttled between a small classroom and an outdoor playground.  The infant classrooms, for example, are clustered together into a "village" with an open indoor gross motor play area called a piazza.  Each village has an outdoor play area as well.  This is very unique.  I've toured multiple daycares in Kentucky and most are not this open with natural lighting.  You might not think this is important but if you were in a small classroom day in an day out you would start feeling cramped too.
-The approach believes in parent involvement.  Clifton School has a PTA that meets on a regular basis and generates money through fundraising.  Each class has at least one class rep.  Parents for each classroom are put on an email list, so concerns can be addressed.  There are multiple ways in which you can submit concerns from the classroom to the administrative level.  This is unique too.  Again, multiple daycares in Georgia and Kentucky DO NOT allow this level of parent involvement (eg kindercare, primrose, clarian place).
3)Great use of resources
-Each classroom has a digital camera.  The teachers take pictures of the kids during the day and write a small one slide powerpoint that goes out to the parents' email list.  You really feel connected to what the kids are doing that day.  It gave me a smile at the end of my day to see an email with a picture of my son playing a drum.  I used to send the email attachments to grandparents to let them know how my little one was doing.
-The Clairmont Campus now has access to fresh fruits and vegetables from a local farm.  Parents place orders and pick up their produce at the Clairmont location.  This is a great sustainable living initiative.
-They hire real photographers from the community to come take pictures of kids for class picture day.  They have a music teacher who sits down with individual classes.  My son got to see someone play a harpsichord when he was 18 months old.
4)Great teachers- great education backgrounds and they love the kids.  When my son was about to move, tears were shed by teachers and administration.  I really felt like I lost a second family.

What I didn't like:
1)It's been mentioned on Google Reviews that the administration isn't responsive to parent concerns.  I did have an issue with the closure-due-to weather policy and didn't get feedback.  I'm not a pushy parent and ended up not caring.  The truth is that there are multiple ways to communicate with the administration, unlike other day cares.  If I were pushy enough, I could've brought it up at a PTA meeting.  I remember the parents got upset that the teachers were only sending out daily word ppts instead of ppts with pictures, and someone posted a complaint to the parent email listserv.  The problem was resolved that week.  
2)Clifton School is only open to Emory and CDC employees.  I'm not entirely sure of all the reasons for this but it's really not fair to keep this great school confined to a small group of people.  Clifton School will now be receiving a Georgia lottery funded pre-K and enrollment has to be open to the community.  Maybe this will change their opinions.  
3)The price!  This school is expensive and I'd like to believe it's worth it.  The school grounds, technologies, and equipment are really kept up nicely.  Parents of infants have Similac available as an optional part of the program.  We cut down on formula costs after the switch to Similac.
4)Long wait list- I applied in late Summer of 2012, delivered Sept 2012, and my son didn't come off the wait list until May 2013. 

Boy, I could write more but it looks like Yelp won't allow it.  I hope this gives a little more info than the angry reviews out there."}],"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingValue":5,"reviewCount":1}}

{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Friends School of Atlanta","telephone":"(404) 373-8746","address":{"streetAddress":"862 Columbia Dr","addressLocality":"Decatur","addressCountry":"US","addressRegion":"GA","postalCode":"30030"},"review":[{"author":"Delia S.","datePublished":"2019-11-12","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"If you want your kids to be more than just smart, to be Great human beings, This is your place. The whole culture puts being caring, honest,  upfront, and respectful front and center. I see it in my kids every day. (ok, almost every day. They're still humans! :))
But they really do learn in a much more varied 'landscape' of people, of cultures, family structures and points of view and they are better for it. My kids are learning, and most importantly, they are happy and confident, they feel loved and like they "belong" at their school. 
(They beg me to stay at aftercare to play with their friends!)"},{"author":"Cecily T.","datePublished":"2019-11-07","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"When it came time to find a kindergarten for my son, I knew that I wanted a setting with small class sizes, skillful teachers, and a focus on academics. However, as a psychologist, I also knew that I wanted a school that had a focus on social-emotional development. I feel so lucky to have found the Friends School for my son. They sincerely practice what they preach. My son has ADHD, and the teachers were exceptional in identifying his needs, using targeted strategies to assist him, and communicating with me about ways to support him. Despite his challenges, they never lost sight of his unique strengths. Now that he is in first grade, he is thriving. And, the beauty of it is, because it's a small school, his current teachers already have some familiarity with him and have been able to give me great feedback about his improvement. 

The focus on ensuring that kids are well-rounded citizens is also a real asset for FSA. My son is courteous, kind, and socially aware. He talks about helping the homeless, eating healthy foods, and caring for the environment. He gets adequate exercise and sunlight during the school day (which research shows is linked to greater energy and concentration). He is learning conflict management skills, mindfulness, empathy, and how to be a good member of a team. As someone who works with business leaders, I know that these lessons will be invaluable in his life. I once told the headmaster that he radiates warmth. His demeanor is so kind, upbeat, and positive - he never looks like he's going through the motions. I believe that he sets a great tone for the rest of the school. I can't rave enough about FSA. I'm so lucky that we found it!"},{"author":"Pamela G.","datePublished":"2018-10-08","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"We decided to go to Friends because of the environment they've created. We wanted our child to not only learn the academics but also have a parallel set of values at school- that he is respected, that he respects others and his community, that kindness and compassion are equally, if not more, important and that participation in his community is a responsibility. He comes home talking about social justice, and equality and asking questions that I never had the chance to think about until college. 
Additionally, our son is excelling academically- in areas where he needed more challenge, they gave it to him. In areas where he needed more support, they gave it to him. He has great, big ideas and they allow for exploration and deep dive into topics that are of interest to the student."},{"author":"Jack R.","datePublished":"2012-06-08","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"What a great place to put your kid. The school's commitment to diversity is unmatched in Atlanta."},{"author":"Caitlin D.","datePublished":"2013-03-20","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"My son went to middle school here for three years. We generally weren't worried about him academically, but boy were we impressed with the way FSA teachers challenged him, made him think, and allowed him to take the time to REALLY learn about topics that interested him.

FSA doesn't stress tests, especially not standardized tests. High-stakes standardized testing was why I wanted him OUT of pubic schools. But I do find it interesting that the very school that did NOT stress over testing was the very one that made a real difference when he did finally take a standardized (although not a "high-stakes") test three years later.

FSA teachers are some of the most dedicated teachers there are--they take time to get to know each child individually, carefully construct lessons, and "kid-watch" to understand how to ensure that every individual child reaches his or her potential. The teachers are masters of their craft. They stay on top of professional learning and collaboratively work to construct challenging curricula. I cannot recommend this school enough!"}],"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingValue":5,"reviewCount":5}}
